segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorn on Tuesday, June 1st, 1993, at the University of Texas at Austin Astronomy Department.
And, well, to start off, why don't you introduce yourself, give your full name.
Okay, my name is William Hamilton Jeffries.
Actually, I'm the third in that line that bears that name.
And I'm the Harlan J. Smith Professor of Astronomy, Centennial Professor of Astronomy at the University of Texas.
OK. Just for the record, when were you born and where?
OK. Born 1940, July 8, New Bedford, Massachusetts.
OK. And when did you first get interested in astronomy?
Oh, when I was quite young, probably around 10 or 11.
What was the thing?
Was there a thing?
Well, there were a couple of incidents.
My father, who is and was, of course, at the time a clergyman, always was interested in science, had taught at the Episcopal Academy outside Philadelphia, where he had also gone to school.
And he was the chaplain there for a few years during the war, Second World War, for those of us that remember that sort of thing.

And there was a colleague of his named Bob Nethery, N-E-A-T-H-E-R-Y, who was one of the science teachers at that school and who also moonlighted as a planetarium lecturer at the Fels Planetarium in Philadelphia.
And one day, I recall, I was just thinking about this a few months ago, in fact, that my father took me to see
the planetarium show, and he introduced me to his friend Bob Mithery after the show, who then proceeded to show me how the planetarium projector worked, which was quite impressive for me at that age.
So that was one of the things.
The other thing was that somebody, and I don't recall who it was, gave me a book on astronomy as a birthday present or a Christmas present.
And so I read it through and found it fascinating.
about the time that I decided that astronomy was pretty interesting stuff, although I didn't actually make up my mind to become an astronomer until probably mid-teens.
Where'd you go to undergrad school?
I went to Wesleyan University in Connecticut, worked for Charlie Gasteyer, who is now dead, measuring plates, and Leo
Stern, I guess it was.
Sterns?
Was it Leo?
Was the director of the observatory, or was at the observatory.
And I actually came the year that Thornton Page joined the faculty at Wesleyan as the director of the observatory.
What year was that?
That was 1958.
What was your major?
I majored in astronomy.
Took a bunch of physics.
Spent a lot of time in the observatory.
worked for Heinz Eichhorn.
He got the first computer on campus, and we learned how to program that by reading the instruction manuals.
Miles Standish was an undergraduate at Wesleyan during that period of time, had just graduated when that computer came, and he went
to Westland as a graduate student for two years, took a master's degree in astronomy while I was finishing up my bachelor's degree, so we did this together pretty much.
When did you graduate?
Graduated in 62.
Okay, and where'd you go to grad school?
Went to Yale.
Okay, why?
Well, because I was interested in sort of classical
aspects of astronomy.

I'd done some astrometry for my honors paper at Wesleyan, and Heinz Eichhorn, whom I'd worked with fairly closely, suggested that Yale would be a good place to go, and in fact that was the only place I applied to.
Good thing they accepted it.
When did you get your Ph.D.?
And what was the topic of your thesis?
I studied some dynamical systems of two degrees of freedom.
Okay, then it's time to get a job.
So what did you do?
Well, to explain that, you've got to talk about Yale, because I was at Yale when Harlan was there.
He left in 1963.
Of course, therefore, my first year was the year that Harlan was still there.
I remember the first time I saw Harlan, he had this crew cut, and he looked like a student.
I thought he was just a graduate student.
I didn't realize that he was about to become a director in a major observatory.
And Harlan, in fact, one of the first things he did was to tell me that he had some
there was this interesting object, 3C273, and that he had access to plates from the plate library at Harvard where, of course, he'd gone to school.

And so he got access to those plates, said, you might want to measure the proper motion of this object because it's very strange and we don't know whether it's a galactic object or extragalactic or what.

I had access to a plate measuring machine at Wesleyan and I measured the plates and I did photometry on the plates and computed the proper motion of 36273 and found that the proper motion was, as far as anybody could tell, zero, which was a pretty good indication that it wasn't too close by to us, certainly not a neutron star or something like that.
Harlan then arranged for me to give a paper on this at the first Texas symposium on relativistic astrophysics and gravitational collapse, I guess it was.
I gave my paper and said that I thought this object was at least such and such a number of parsecs away.
And somebody in the audience said, how much is that in real units?
Somebody else in the audience shouted back, three times ten to the eighteenth centimeters per parsec.
Well, that was a number I didn't have in my head in those days, but I do now.
Harlan also arranged for me to be one of three American students during the summer of 1963 to get NATO scholarships to go to Turkey to attend a
series of courses on mostly dynamical type subjects.
George Kantopoulos was there.
Sir Richard Woolley was there.
Smart was there.
He was still alive at the time.
Gave lectures.
I've got the lectures here somewhere.
I don't know where.
Boring writer.
Oh, well, yeah.
I didn't think too much of his lectures.
Cantopoulos' lectures were very exciting.
Michel Hnon was there.
That was when he was just beginning to do his work on chaos.
So it was a very worthwhile experience.
The other two students were David Morrison, who is what now director of Ames, at Ames.
Or something, yeah.
Yeah.
And Jerry Newsome.
who's in Ohio somewhere, N-E-W-S-O-N-E. And the other thing that we were talking about, you mentioned Brian Marsden being at Yale.
Brian, of course, married Nancy while he was still a student at Yale, decided that marriage was a pretty good thing, had a cousin, which he
Nancy had a cousin that she thought she would like to fix up with one of the astronomers because she was kind of interested in astronomy, too.
And I was the one that got picked, and my wife, in fact, is Nancy Morrison's cousin.
And also, yeah, Eric Beaujean.
B-O-Z-Y-A-N, Arikel, it's an Armenian name, who was a graduate student at Yale at the time.
His sister married my second cousin, so there's another little connection there.
Probably useless information, but there you are.
You never know, you never know.
Well, what went on with Harlem at Yale?
Well, he sort of just was rather encouraging.
I don't recall that I ever took any lectures from him.
I don't think I did.
But he was sort of an encouraging kind of a figure and encouraged me to keep at this work on 373.
Clearly, he liked me.
And I liked him.
It was hard not to like.
I went to their home once.
They had a sort of a party for the graduate students.
And we all sat around in the room and played various games of sorts, which he was very fond of, thought the family was very fond of.
What was his position at the time?
Was he an associate professor?
He was an assistant professor, I think, possibly associate.
I'm not sure about that.
He did not have tenure.
I guess.
He would not have had tenure.
That was one of the reasons why he came to Texas.
Was he forced out of there or not?

And the reason is that Art Code says that he wrote a very strong letter of recommendation for Harlem and wrote an even stronger letter back afterwards saying what fools there were to let him get away.
Well, we graduate students, of course, weren't privy to a lot of information of that sort.

The impression that we got, or at least that I got, was that he had not received tenure and that I know the graduate students were rather upset that he had left because they had a fairly good opinion of him.
I heard somewhere that he almost took a job at the University of Virginia.
I don't know anything about that.
Sorry, Frederick might know.
He's a good person to talk to.
So that puts Harlan in Austin.
That puts Harlan in Austin.
Long about 1964, I kept in touch with him.
He told me at the occasion of the Texas Symposium, which was November 1963, just after President Kennedy had been assassinated, and the
worthies of Dallas were all worried about the image of their city, because of course that's where it was held.
And after the meeting, he brought me down to Austin.
We drove down in Frank Edmonds' old Peugeot 403.
You remember that, don't you?
And then
I think that's, yeah, that's right.
And then we flew out to West Texas, because he was trying to get Jim Douglas to come here at the time.
And we flew around the Mitchell Flats area and saw where, was that on a different occasion?
I'm not sure that that was that occasion or another occasion that I came to Texas.
because I came here twice before I actually was hired.
Visited Austin.
I think that may have been that trip, but Jim might remember which two occasions it was.
We sort of flew around, and then we drove out there, I guess, and looked at this optical flat at...
this wavelength piece of land and saw the observatory.
But anyway, on one of those occasions, Harlan said that he would like me to come here.
This is before I finished my degree.
And along in 1964, Thornton Page left
about 64.
He left the observatory, that's right.
And he went to Houston, I guess.
I saw him in February.
Because he had an accident in which he'd lost a good deal of the sight of one of his eyes.
And I think that was difficult for him
to continue at Wesleyan in the position that he was in.
At any rate, he had left.
And he was not there.
And Heinz Eichhorn had gone.
He had left also.
And so there I was.
They needed somebody to run the astrometry program.
And so I ran the astrometry program during that last year when I was at Wesleyan.
Harlan was afraid that I wouldn't finish my dissertation.
He was somewhat trepidatious about it.
So you were doing your dissertation at Yale, but you were spending most of your time at Wesleyan.
A good deal of my time at Wesleyan.
I taught a course there.
But I did finish it up.
And then Harlan had put my name in for a Sloan fellowship, which I got.
And so the first year,
Instead of going to Texas, I resigned from Yale and accepted this position as assistant professor here, but would leave for the first year, which was kind of an unusual arrangement.
But so that I could take advantage of this post-doctoral fellowship and the Slum Fellowship.
And what I did was I latched on to Juergen Moser

was a mathematician at New York University at the Koran Institute, and who was one of the three people whose name is in the Kahn theory, the theory of the existence of toroidal solutions to dynamical systems.
It's a very important theory these days.
So, I studied with him.
He was very, from my point of view, a very pure mathematician.
Were you working on just systems in general?
We were working on dynamical systems.

When I was at NYU and also at Stanford, because he took a sabbatical at Stanford and I just followed him out there, we worked on a paper and published a paper on the three-body problem, in which we showed that certain
There were solutions of the real full three-body problem that were not the standard triangular solutions that were stable, and we described their properties and so forth.
I also worked on mercury.
The fact that mercury rotated in 59 days had just been discovered, and we discussed that, and I discussed that in terms of some of Moser's work.
I worked on some periodic...
Solutions and the Restricted Problem with Miles Standish, which we published.
And there were some other things, too.
I forgot what they were.
So I took the fall in New York City.
The lights went out.
Had a great time.
Went out to Stanford for the spring semester.
In this, what year was that?
This was 1965, 66 academic year.
attended some lectures on quantum field theory that Sidney Drell was giving in the math department, met some famous mathematicians, and generally had a pretty good time.
Then came here in the fall of 66, just after Charles Whitten shot all those people off the tower.
My father-in-law, we were sitting around the television set.
My father-in-law turned to me after.
Walter Cronkite came out with his news and said, Bill, isn't that where you're going with my daughter?
Having just gotten married in 1966 in June.
Now, since you've been here, what have you been working on in general?
How's that changed?
Well, first few years, I spent mostly working on various problems in celestial mechanics.
I built...
a program to study the surfaces of section in the restricted three-body problem.
And it did some work on an atlas of those surfaces of section which give information about stability regimes.
Got interested in non-numerical algebra calculations, symbolic algebra calculations, and wrote
a processor to do that, and we used that on some dynamic systems, some satellites in particular.
Did little observing, not a whole lot, but Darryl Mulholland was here at the time, Pete Shells was here at the time.
Darryl and Pete sort of got involved in observing satellites of the outer planets, and I went out and did some of those observations.
And then along 1970,
Seven or eight, I've forgotten.
Whenever the Space Telescope project got started, we proposed to the Space Telescope to be the astrometry team, and we got that contract.
That's what I've been pretty much doing ever since.
Haven't done so much dynamical astronomy since then.
There are certain people that actually
His name is David Dvorkin, here at the Space Museum, who claims that celestial mechanics isn't really astronomy.
Well, I can appreciate that comment because celestial mechanics is very closely related to mathematics.
A lot of mathematics has come out of it, but it's mathematics which is applied to problems
planetary motion and also problems in stellar astronomy.

It's hard to draw the line because a lot of what people have done in celestial mechanics is also applicable to questions in galactic structure or the structure of the rings of Saturn and other planetary rings and so forth.
So to say that it is not astronomy at all I think is stretching the case but it is more
mathematical in many ways than most areas of astronomy are.
Well, I'm going to include it anyway because Simon Newcomb, after all, considered himself an astronomer.
He certainly was not a spectroscopist.
Right.
Well, Brouwer considered the definitely astronomical area of astrometry to be the observational arm of celestial mechanics.
That was his term for it.
And, of course, Brower was responsible in large part for reviving celestial mechanics in this country and was pretty moribund.

He came along and established a number of summer institutes and other opportunities for people to learn about celestial mechanics and established at Yale a very thriving group of people in celestial mechanics who are now out in the world doing their thing.
Miles Standish, for example, has just demonstrated, fairly convincingly, that there is no Planet X.
That was just within the past few weeks that it was announced.
So, he was part of that group that was at Yale with me.
You've mentioned an interesting point, which is that celestial mechanics was pretty dead feel in the, well even in the 50s and 60s.
Until satellites came along.

Until satellites came along, and then all of a sudden people realized that they had to have people that were trained in this area in order to support not only the civilian space program but also the military space program.
Well, there was what?
There were Brower and Clements, and who was it?
Kurgut?
Kurgut.
And then a few people at the Naval Observatory.
Yeah, that was pretty much it.
Clements, of course, was at the Naval Observatory at the time and came to Yale after he retired.
There was Boris Garfinkel, who's still active, at least it was the last time I looked.
But Peter Musen, another one.
You know, see, I did my doctoral dissertation on radiation pressure effects on our satellite
Ah yes, McVitie was another one of those.
Vinty, John Vinty, when he was at MIT.
But that was, you know, basically that was it.
Yeah, and these guys were all getting on in years.
There were really no young people involved in that field.
They'd all gone into astrophysics.
And so what happened when satellites became important was that a number of people
got interested in celestial mechanics and dynamical astronomy that probably would not have done so had it not been for that particular evidence.
I want to get back to that, but I want to ask you now, when did you show up?
I think you mentioned it here at UT.
66, August of 1966.
Well, what was the faculty like then?
How many folks were there?
I think there were seven.
Let me see.
Let's see, Andy Young was here, Frank Edmonds was here, Bob Tull was here, Gerard de Beauvelure, Harlan, of course, Terry Deeney, myself.
Is that seven?
I think so.
I think I would have.
And Jim Douglas.
So I was the eighth.
I was the eighth person.
There were seven before I came.
There was eight afterwards.
And this building hadn't been built.
This building had not been built.
We were in the old physics building, which is over near the tower.
This department's a lot bigger now, so is the McDonald's staff.
Better?
Better.
It is.
Oh, yeah.
The young people that we've brought into this department, some of them are really outstanding.
You just take a look at the prizes that they've been taking home.
Did you, well, it's an obvious question.
You're taking NASA money now.
Have you done so in the past before the HST?
Not personally.
I did take some NASA money.
Indirectly, Byron Tapley had some which I was using to support some computing and also to support publication of papers.
I was involved also with this outer planet satellite project that Darryl was the PI on.
But that was pretty much it.
Well, you have had
recent experience.
How do you think NSA handles these things, either in the past or today?
I mean, do they micromanage?
Do they Well, I've not been micromanaged.
I can only speak to my own experience.
That's just exactly what I want.
I've been given fairly free reign to do as I thought needed to be done.
There have been the first twelve or so years, however, thirteen maybe,
were a contract, not a grant.
And so there were certain reporting requirements and so forth that were laid upon us.
And there were certain things that had to be done.
So what was the contract for?
This was the contract for the HST's astrometry science team, is what it was called, something like that.
Get the exact name over from the people there.
But it was run out of Marshall.
Most of the science team got their money from Goddard.
But you know how the HST project was fragmented among several different centers so that they could sort of spread the money around.
And Marshall had the prime contract with the Optical Telescope Assembly.
And the Optical Telescope Assembly included the fine guidance sensors.
And the fine guidance sensors were the astrometric instrument, in quotes.
And therefore, my money came from Marshall and not from Goddard.
Are you getting any results?
Some.
It's been a long, difficult period for us.
Yeah, they can't show pretty pictures of what you're doing.
Well, that's part of it.
And part of it has been that not so much the optical problems, although the optical problems do pose difficulties for us, but they're of a different nature
And they are not the principal problem that we have faced.
The principal problem that we have faced is, until fairly recently, the telescope was not a very stable platform.
The problems with the solar panels, which bend when you go in and out of the terminator, have caused a lot of stability problems for us, in particular loss of lock problems.
And it wasn't until they finally got a much better
pointing control system algorithm in the telescope that we were able to rely on it as a platform and actually take the calibration data that we needed to take.
This parallel between planetary astronomy and celestial mechanics is pretty interesting in that both kind of
died lousy early in this century, and they were represented by just a few people, and then when the space age came, bang.
So let me ask you this.
Let's talk about celestial mechanics now.
What was NASA's influence on that the other day?
Well, they've done pretty well without N.A.S.A.
funding or did it work?
Celestial Mechanics?
Yeah.
Oh, I don't think it would have done well at all without the funding that's come into it, particularly in the early years because most of that, well, D.O.D.
also provided money for some of these efforts.
Like to me.
Yeah.
As a pacifist, I would have had difficulty taking D.O.D.
money and I've never
accepted DOD money with the exception of that trip that I took to Turkey, which was actually under NATO and not under DOD itself, although probably the money originally originated there.
Harlan was also a Quaker, as I am, but he felt that it was a good thing to take money from the Department of Defense because it
then could not be used for other things.
I don't think that that's a true perception of the way things actually work, but that's sometimes the excuse that he gave me.
So we differed in that respect.
But I think that a major portion of the money that went into celestial mechanics did come from NASA.
An awful lot of, if you take a look at
bibliographies and acknowledgments on papers, you'll very often see NASA support in many of those early papers.
If you go look around 1900, here's your big-time astronomers, our celestial mechanicians, all right?
Simon Newcomb, Moulton, Professor Moriarty.
And then, I mean, that was really the in thing, just like gravitational waves are now, or the way astrophysics was in the 1930s.
Why did it die?
I mean, did it run up against the wall, or was it just there were so many other things going on?
Well, I don't know.
That's an interesting question.
I've not really thought about it terribly much.
Clearly, fields only continue to prosper if you can get new students interested in those fields.

I think that's a major situation because in the 20s and 30s, there was, as you correctly point out, a flowering of astrophysics and people were going into that field because now it was possible to learn things about stars.
Yeah, the hot shots like Menzel and everything.
It was possible to learn things about stars that could not have been learned before
This was partly due to new instrumentation.
It was also partly due to the fact that you had quantum mechanics, which enabled you to do correct physics in a way that was not possible.
We began to understand why stars shine in a detailed way, and we were able to make detailed
to get a detailed understanding of what the physics in the atmospheres of stars was.
And so that's where the best minds went, because that's where the interest was.
That's where the cutting edge was.
And so people weren't going into celestial mechanics, mostly.
And people weren't going into astrometry, mostly, even though there was and still is a very, very
great need for basic astronomical data, they're not glamorous fields.
It takes too long to get a parallax.
It takes years and years to get the data to get a parallax.
And then you look back on your life and you've published 30 parallaxes, or 40 parallaxes, or 100 parallaxes, and that's it.
When you could have done something much splashier.
And so I think that's probably the reason.
It's a combination of things.
Well, it is odd, because I got in on it just while I went over to the astronomy department, because they had just started their PhD program in Illinois, and then the Russians put up satellites.
Yeah, I watched that satellite from the roof of our house in 1957.
We were doing it from the observatory, too.
And I was always like a year or two behind the money.
After a while an essay got going and I started handing out money, but I always just missed all that.
Let me ask you about Harlem.
What's the first time you met him?
I think the first time I met him, I'm not absolutely certain of this, he may have come to Wesleyan, and I might have met him when he came to Wesleyan, but it didn't stick in my memory.
The first time I remember meeting him was at the AAS meeting in 1965, which was held at Yale.
Oh, and that reminds me, there was one other astronomical influence on my life that I don't think I told you, that I didn't tell you about.
and I remember this because he was also at Yale.
At Michigan, there was an astronomer named Dean McLaughlin.
Now, in 1947, Dean McLaughlin, by the way, worked for, during the summertime, he moonlighted as a geologist for the Pennsylvania Geological Survey.
And in 1946...
He predicted volcanoes on Mars.
Could very well be.
I didn't.
didn't know that.
But at any rate, in 1947 we had, I was seven years old, we moved to a farm outside of Philadelphia near Doylestown, which was in a town called Chalfont, Quaker country.
I do want to talk a bit about that because Harlem is a Quaker and so we've had some relationships along that line.
But at any rate, we moved out there.
And one day, Dean McLaughlin came wandering up the crypt bed that we owned half of, looking for rocks, came knocking on our door.
Had my mother asking for some water or something like that.
My mother invited him in and started to chat.
It turned out he was an astronomer.
Well, he had a most marvelous compass.
You know, a magnetic compass with bells and whistles and all these things on it that geologists like to carry with them.
And I was fascinated by that.
That was the first real astronomer I ever met.
We kept up with him, at least my parents did, until he died.
You know, Christmas cards and stuff like that.
But at any rate, that meeting at Yale, I think, was the first time that I actually met Harlan, although I'm not absolutely certain about that.
Miles Standish and I both went to that meeting.
We had a good time thinking about all the papers on polarization of radio sources, which was big in those days.
We decided that all the papers were exactly alike.
The only thing that changed was the name of the source and the percent of polarization.
Do you think Arlen could have done even more if he'd done a little less?
In what way?
Well, he was always driven.
Always.
And, you know, one reason your heart muscle tends to last a fairly long time is that it rests most of the time.
Or at least part of the time you cycle.
And Harlan never seemed to do that.
No, he was certainly always working.
I don't know.
I think that was just the way he was.
He, I don't think, would have been comfortable not doing that stuff.
Certainly, his longevity was not affected by that.
And that was a completely different situation and just an unhappy chance that he got the virulent cancer that he did.
So I don't think that that shortened his life in any way.
Maybe one could argue that there are things he might have applied himself to that would have been more fruitful than some of the things that, in fact, he did spend a lot of time with.
But that's a matter of judgment.
And of course, anybody's career is going to have things that .
He did a lot of things, so not everything is going to be at the same level.
Right, right.
Someone was saying
the other day that Harlan was really loyal and maybe carried that a little bit too far in some cases.
I think that that may be true, yeah.
There were projects which should have been cut off sooner.
You're talking Gribble Ball?
I think we're talking Gribble Ball in particular.
I think that was the one project that was most visible and to which a large amount of money, you know, a comparatively large amount of money went without any real
What do you think is the status of astronomy at the University of Texas now?
I think we're a pretty good department.
Do the higher-ups care about that?
You mean over in the tower?
You mean the big shots?
I think they do, to a certain degree.
We've got a new president now, and I don't know how
clued into the excellence of our program he is.
And so we'll find out in due course, I suppose.
I always felt that we got support from Bill Cunningham while he was president, and he's now down in the system, so I think he still does support us.
They've put their prestige where their mouths are in the sense that they've decided to go ahead with the SST project, which is, I think, a very important project for our department.
Now, I guess I should talk to the people at SST.
And, well, I'm going to be talking with Tom Barton about that, too.
But it always seemed to me weird, the way this thing's been going on, that, you know, well, you can't really go out and get money.
I always thought that the way to run a place was to say, go get all the money you can get.
And, you know, I mean, gee whiz.
I'll tell you one thing.
When I was in headquarters, when Harlan was here, when the 107-inch telescope opportunity came along,
What was his name?
Dr. Death.
You know, the president of Boston University.
Oh, you mean John Silber, yes.
John Silber was the dean.
And he didn't go fooling around.
What, NASA wants to give us $3 million for a telescope?
Hell yes.
That was it, you know.
Well, the difference is that with the SST, the money has to be privately raised.
And I think the administration was concerned that...

the money that we, A, might not be able to raise all the money that we needed, or that, and this is another important thing, or that, B, we would raise the money that we said that we needed and it would turn out to cost more than we thought.
And I still think that they do have in mind the 107-inch, which was well over budget.
I remember that very well.
Tell me, Harlan's
One of the people I can't interview, the other one is Kuiper.
Tell me something about Harlan.
Tell me all you know about Harlan.
All I know about Harlan, well, that's all.
You know, please send me everything you have on this ground.
I'm not interested in his great scientific accomplishments or anything.
My fondest memories of Harlan are as a friend.
He recognized my talents in a way more than I recognized my own, certainly when he first met me.
And he laid opportunities in my path that I might not have had otherwise.
He and Joan joined the friends meeting
Connecticut.
I don't know which monthly meeting it was.
Joan would be able to tell you that.
Back when they were there and in fact even today I think one of Joan's very closest friends is was a member of that meeting and
They still live in Connecticut.
They came down here during the time that Harlan was ill and then after he died and really played a very major role in helping the family through this crisis.
Charles Chu and I've forgotten his wife's name.
That's terrible.
Betty, I think it is.
but I'm not absolutely certain of that.
But, again, you can ask Joan about that.
By the way, I did see her in January at the AAS meeting, the DPS, too late, Dave Howland, the big award.
And she's agreed to do some interviews.
I'm going to see Jim Douglas tomorrow morning.
He's going to bring what he has.
Right.
And so, at any rate, when we came to Austin, I had...
When I was young, I had attended the Friends Meeting out in Doylestown, Pennsylvania, when we were out there in the countryside there.
My father, although he was an Episcopal clergyman, he was going through a crisis at that point.
And so we started attending the Friends Meeting there.
And I got introduced and always liked the Quakers.
And when we came here, we joined this meeting.
Harlan and Joan had already transferred their membership down here.
And we've been involved with Friends Meeting here for quite a long time, since about 25 years.
So, you know, I have memories of Harlan making ice cream for the Friends Meeting.
Peach ice cream, it always seemed to be.
It could have been vanilla, but very often it was peach.
He loved it.
And he'd bring the old hand-wound ice cream freezer to meeting, and we'd all take turns cranking it, and then we'd have it for dessert after our potluck lunch on some Sunday, some hot Sunday.
And that was wonderful.
And he would have the meeting over to his home for Christmas on a number of occasions.
They had wonderful toys in that house.
Puzzles, really solid mathematical type puzzles that the kids owned.
Real mind benders.
Real mind benders.
And they were the kind of puzzle that would last forever.
Not something that would break five minutes after you got it.
And so I always felt that that was a very wonderful kind of thing
Well, why don't you just...
